
Here is a script for you to update `persistent_peers` setting in `config.toml`. Stale peers can cause node inefficiency over time, so the script below selects a few random live peers.

```bash
PEERS=3992c3e8e9024d50656e398951fbf5a8df26f6ec@167.235.3.247:26626,9c9f030298bdda9ca69de7db8e9a3aef33972fba@142.132.131.249:31656,4ff3fd3cece803d8a478e405c2868ebc12e56200@15.235.115.150:10400,601cbd873d1aca5c0282991f16a6f0c833d713cd@178.18.244.191:26656,819b6299c69a473d92b42280cc2f3bd1020c9c5a@204.216.222.165:26656
sed -i.bak -e "s/^persistent_peers *=.*/persistent_peers = \"$PEERS\"/" ~/.bitsongd/config/config.toml

sudo systemctl restart bitsongd
sudo journalctl -fu bitsongd --no-hostname -o cat
```

## Our peer for BitSong
When you state-sync, you might also consider adding [NODERS]TEAM state-sync peer to your persistent_peers setting in `config.toml`.

```bash
b347b47a650981b2e12782e92cf26ba8aa0148c9@bitsong-rpc.noders.services:20656
```
